climbs.name: Veranda
climbs.fa: Matt Scherer, Aly Bailey, Bryan Hamlin 7/9/2018 Ground up

content.description: Start in the crack with huge jugs surrounding it, follow this to the top and then take the sweet left angling crack to the top and build anchor in crack. rap off slung horn
content.protection: finger to hand sized gear, RP's, C3's
content.location: located on the northwest side of balcony point in 1/2 gully

climbs.name: Under an Open Sky
climbs.fa: Mark Rafferty, Rich Ellison, & Ryan Hoben, July 2018,Ground up

content.description:
A surprisingly long route that follows a series of dihedrals with gear right where you need em.

 On the Southwest side of balcony point (just uphill from Gods Own Drunk) follow two small dihedrals moving up and left transitioning to the next. Climbing thins out for a few moves where you will pass a bolt, continue straight up in a shallow dihedral up a hand and finger crack finish. 

 Two rope rappel: Bolted/webbing anchor
content.protection: Doubles of small pro up to a #.3, singles of #.4 - #4, nuts/Rps Long slings
content.location: Located on the Southwest side of the formation. To the left of the large major dihedral on the south side.

climbs.name: North Crack
climbs.fa: Barry Corbet, Jake Breitenbach, Charles Plummer '56

content.description: This is a great climb.  Start by climbing the first 2 pitches of the east face route on Spire Two.  Then, when at the saddle between Spire Two and Balcony Point, climb up to the obvious beautiful splitter crack that goes almost to the summit of Balcony Point.  Climb this, the hardest move being pulling through a bulgy crack to the top of the pillar.
content.protection: Standard Rack.  The 3rd pitch is a perfect crack that eats up gear.

content.description:
Balcony Point is named just for that, a large ledge on the south side of the rock.  It can be mistaken for Spire Two from a distance, as it completely obstructs the view from the parking lot.  If you look at the beta photo of the Cathedral Spires, the one that I have numbered as 2 is really Balcony Point.   

  This is a large spire, and it requires around 3 pitches to get to the top.  One common way of climbing it is a beautiful crack that leads up from the saddle of Spire Two and Balcony Point.  Descend by rappelling from the summit of Balcony Point to the saddle with Spire Two, and then follow its rappel down the east face route (two ropes necessary).
